item.title: The Importance of Brand in an Era of Digital Darwinism - Brian Solis
item.description: The Importance of Brand in an Era of Digital Darwinism: Part of an unpublished appendix for The End of Business ... http://t.co/OLwPdu3d
item.content:encoded: The Importance of Brand in an Era of Digital Darwinism: Part of an unpublished appendix for The End of Business ... http://t.co/OLwPdu3d Think of your favorite brand, and the first thing to come to mind is likely a logo, such as the Coca-Cola scripting, a tag-line, such as Nike’s “Just do it,” or a jingle – remember the Oscar Meyer Wiener song? These may be the aspects of a brand you remember, but they are no longer the most important aspects of branding today. Identity, persona, essence and promise, are the new kings and queens of the branding kingdom, thanks to technology and the deeper connections it opens up between brands and consumers. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: briansolis.com

item.title: 3 Lessons On How Not To Use Social Media To Create Change
item.description: 3 lessons on how NOT to use social media to make change: http://t.co/lhNvjvur @jeremyheimans @emjacobi @emilymaynot @UltraViolet
item.content:encoded: 3 lessons on how NOT to use social media to make change: http://t.co/lhNvjvur @jeremyheimans @emjacobi @emilymaynot @UltraViolet Almost 15 years after Moveon.org first started flooding inboxes, online organizers and movement entrepreneurs are aging past their click here, click there, click everywhere adolescence. Organizations aiming to mobilize people to take online action are becoming wise, intentional, and strategic about the limitations of Internet-based interventions in creating deep, long lasting social change. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: fastcoexist.com

item.title: Rush Limbaugh, AOL Part Ways
item.description: Rush Limbaugh, AOL Part Ways http://t.co/0EfO62Sq
item.content:encoded: Rush Limbaugh, AOL Part Ways http://t.co/0EfO62Sq WASHINGTON -- AOL, the parent company of The Huffington Post, has become the eighth advertiser to pull its money from Rush Limbaugh's syndicated radio program since he called Georgetown law student Sandra Fluke, who spoke out in favor of contraception coverage, a "slut" and a "prostitute" last week, according to a high-level Huffington Post source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, but with a distinctly Greek accent. "At AOL one of our core values is that we act with integrity," said Maureen Sullivan, an AOL spokeswoman who confirmed the decision. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: huffingtonpost.com

item.title: Bryan Stevenson: We need to talk about an injustice | Video on TED.com
item.description: MUST SEE TED TALK: Bryan Stevenson: We need to talk about an injustice | Video on http://t.co/o5sBbqwE http://t.co/E0uku2Ll
item.content:encoded: MUST SEE TED TALK: Bryan Stevenson: We need to talk about an injustice | Video on http://t.co/o5sBbqwE http://t.co/E0uku2Ll TED Talks In an engaging and personal talk -- with cameo appearances from his grandmother and Rosa Parks -- human rights lawyer Bryan Stevenson shares some hard truths about America's justice system, starting with a massive imbalance along racial lines: a third of the country's black male population has been incarcerated at some point in their lives. These issues, which are wrapped up in America's unexamined history, are rarely talked about with this level of candor, insight and persuasiveness. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: ted.com

item.title: How do blogs need to evolve?
item.description: Good discussion from early blog co. types: How do blogs need to evolve? http://t.co/gbWu3mwd /via @timoreilly
item.content:encoded: Good discussion from early blog co. types: How do blogs need to evolve? http://t.co/gbWu3mwd /via @timoreilly It seems like some of the basic elements of the form, such as comments, have been stuck in a model that doesn't work very well to encourage quality responses and also doesn't fit the way people do things socially online these days. Oddly, a blog comment isn't even as good a social object as a photo. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: branch.com

item.title: Smacketology
item.description: Smacketology: The @Grantland33 tournament to determine The Wire's greatest character http://t.co/6hBl6Y1B
item.content:encoded: Smacketology: The @Grantland33 tournament to determine The Wire's greatest character http://t.co/6hBl6Y1B Did we mention that our esteemed editor-in-chief hung out with President Obama last week? Because that totally happened. Just two regular guys, discussing Linsanity, Blake Griffin's jump shot, what it's like to pitch a baseball while wearing a bulletproof vest, and — as the conversation wound down — The Wire. Asked to name the greatest Wire character of all time (let it never be said that Grantland does not ask the tough questions!), the Commander in Chief didn't hesitate: "It's gotta be Omar, right? I mean, that guy is unbelievable, right?" Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: grantland.com

item.title: Jewish activist to AIPAC: Stop Silencing Dissent!
item.description: Amazing disruption in #AIPAC by @jvplive member http://t.co/uoqnLNBi
item.content:encoded: Amazing disruption in #AIPAC by @jvplive member http://t.co/uoqnLNBi On March 4, 2012, 22 year old member of Young Jewish and Proud (the youth wing of Jewish Voice for Peace) Liza Behrendt stood up at the 2012 AIPAC Policy Conference in a breakout session called "The Struggle to Secure Israel on Campus" to call attention to the silencing of Palestinians— and young Jews who support them — on U.S. campuses. This action was part of OCCUPY AIPAC. www.occupyaipac.org Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: youtube.com

item.title: The Richest 1 Percent Captured 93 Percent Of Income Gains In 2010
item.description: via .@thinkprogress The Richest 1 Percent Captured 93 Percent Of Income Gains In 2010 http://t.co/rRAmBvs1 #p2
item.content:encoded: via .@thinkprogress The Richest 1 Percent Captured 93 Percent Of Income Gains In 2010 http://t.co/rRAmBvs1 #p2 Though the economy is slowly recovering from the Great Recession, large swaths of the American public are still bogged down by joblessness, underwater mortgages, and falling incomes. In fact, “between June 2009, when the recession officially ended, and June 2011, inflation-adjusted median household income fell 6.7 percent, to $49,909.” Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: thinkprogress.org
